conversation.content: [confused] Who are you exactly?

[formal] Deputy US Marshal Sarah Chen, and I need to speak with you about one of your portfolio companies. [pause] Specifically, the founder of DataVault Solutions, the person you know as Marcus Webb.
[shocked] Marcus? [nervously] I just had lunch with him yesterday discussing our Series A round, we're about to wire two million dollars into his company account next week.
[stern] That wire transfer needs to be frozen immediately, sir. [quietly] The person you know as Marcus Webb doesn't exist, at least not in the way you think he does.
[frustrated] What the hell are you talking about? [loudly] I've done extensive background checks, reference calls, I've met his entire team, visited their offices multiple times over the past year!

[empathetically] The background you verified is real, just not originally his. [sighs] Look, I can't discuss the specifics of his situation, but I need to know if he's mentioned any travel plans or sudden changes recently.
This is insane, you're telling me I've invested eight hundred thousand dollars of my fund's money into someone in witness protection? [bitter] My limited partners are going to absolutely destroy me.

[firmly] His business is legitimate, Mr. Harrison, and so is his expertise in encryption technology. [pause] The problem is someone from his past has surfaced, and we have credible intelligence they've tracked him to this city.
[shaky voice] Jesus Christ, is he dangerous? [anxiously] Should I be worried about my other founders, my staff, my family knowing that I've been publicly associated with him?
[reassuringly] He's not the threat.

[desperately] But his company is the cornerstone of my entire fund strategy, we've been featured in TechCrunch, Forbes, everywhere talking about this revolutionary encryption platform. [exhales] If this gets out, my reputation is finished.

[quietly] Your reputation is the least of our concerns right now, Mr. Harrison. [very seriously] The people looking for him have killed three witnesses in the past eighteen months, and they don't care about collateral damage.
[whispering] Oh my God.
[quickly] Which is why I need you to act completely normal for the next forty-eight hours while we relocate him. [firmly] Can you do that without tipping anyone off, including Marcus himself?
[hesitantly] You want me to pretend everything's fine while you're telling me there are killers potentially watching his every move? [sarcastically] Sure, no pressure there.

[stern] This isn't a request, Mr. Harrison, it's a matter of national security and multiple lives are at stake. [pause] Marcus testified against a major international crime syndicate, and his testimony put away people you've definitely read about.

[defeated] So what happens to DataVault, to the technology, to the fifteen employees who think they're building the future? [quietly] They don't deserve to have their lives destroyed because their boss is secretly someone else.
[empathetically] The technology and the company can continue, potentially under new leadership if you move quickly. [sighs] But Marcus, or whoever he becomes next, won't be part of it after Tuesday.
[bitterly] Three years of work, countless hours of mentorship, and he never said a word. [very quietly] I actually thought we were friends beyond just the business relationship.

[warmly] For what it's worth, everything I've seen in our surveillance suggests he genuinely cares about you and this company. [pause] Sometimes the best way to protect people is to never let them know they need protection.

scenario: A seed investor discovers their most promising startup founder is actually in witness protection when a US Marshal arrives at their office.
